reviewText: Viewed: 9/04, 3/06Rate: 23/06: American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt has a new lead character and new director but same story and same crap. Steve James is still the same. So, is there anything new to add for this third sequel? Not really. During American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt, it appeared, to me, that bad guys are practically letting the good guys to win. The phony fight scenes lowered the entertainment value, and the ninjas are so wimpy that I could futilely knock them out. Steve James is the show, but he doesn't save the movie from being a bomb. Phony karate moves, lame villains, lack of plot, and crappy subplots are vices of a bad martial arts movie, and American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt is no exception. Steven Seagal did these films with more class and substance. At least, David Bradley, the lead character of American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt, was able to speak more than Michael Dudikoff did in total through the first two films. I wondered how American Ninja series had survived this long and onto couple more sequels. It's very bewildering. Overall, American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt is an dreadfully made picture that passes off easily as a cheap Z-grade version of Mission: Impossible.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Lunar Strain "Thrash, don't mind if I do"
reviewText: American Ninja 3 suffers greatly without Michael Dudikoff and David Bradley just doesn't have the same touch as the hero of the film. The highlight of AM3 is muscle bound Steve James returning from the first two American Ninja movies. I am a fan of the first two, but I was really disgusted with American Ninja 3. American Ninja 4 is only a hair better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE ABSOLUTE WORST MOVIE IN THE ENTIRE SERIES, PERIOD. THIS TIME, DAVID BRADLEY, WHO PLAYS A NEW AMERICAN NINJA, MUST PREVENT AN EVIL COMPANY FROM UNLEASHING A DEADLY BIOLOGICAL WEAPON. DAVID BRADLEY JUST ISN'T ABLE TO CARRY THIS SERIES THE WAY MICHAEL DUDIKOFF DID. EVEN THOUGH STEVE JAMES CAME BACK FOR THIS ONE, HE'S NOT ABLE TO SAVE THIS ONE. A TOTAL LETDOWN. WHERE IS MICHAEL DUDIKOFF WHEN YOU NEED HIM?
summary: STAY AWAY FROM THIS ONE, YOU'LL BE GLAD YOU DID!

reviewText: After receiving flak for having appeared in the South Africa-filmedAmerican Ninja 2(because the country was still practicing apartheid at the time), original "Ninja" Michael Dudikoff turned down the chance to appear in the second sequel in the franchise, and therein left the door open for David Bradley to kick off his own career as an action hero. "Blood Hunt" is oftentimes considered among the worst installments of the franchise, and most fans tend to turn their noses up at Bradley taking Dudikoff's place...but you know what? I actually prefer this one over half of the other movies, including the original film. While "Blood Hunt" does take a few steps away from the formula of the two features that came before it, they're not entirely unwelcome changes and help make for a film that's best enjoyed by general martial arts and B-movie fans.The story: meeting by chance during a martial arts tournament, karate superstar Sean Davidson (Bradley,Hard Justice) and soldier-turned-competitor Curtis Jackson (Steve James,To Live and Die in L.A.) face a deadly terrorist threat in the form of a engineered virus and an army of ninja.While Michael Dudikoff initiated the series as an actor masquerading as a martial artist, David Bradley enters scene as a martial artist masquerading as an actor. Few folks can deny that Bradley's physical performances blatantly outstrip Dudikoff's, but while Dudikoff may be accused of showing too little human emotion in his acting, Bradley almost definitely shows too much. Nevertheless, I'm fine with David's performance, and he plays well with Steve James, who's once again the most engaging character of the film. Both the lead villain (Marjoe Gortner,Starcrash) and especially his lead lady ninja (Michele Chan, "Danger Bay") are finally given some genuine character roles. Probably the biggest dramatic drawback of the movie is Evan Klisser (Space Mutiny), who gives an okay performance but whose sidekick role was completely unnecessary and just wastes time.Story-wise, the movie is serviceable but not any stronger than the ones that came before it. By now, the prospect of a ninja army seems more mundane and unthreatening that ever before, but obviously having a "ninjette" in charge is a nice touch. The backstory's setup of how Sean lost his father to the hands of main henchman Yehuda Efroni (Braddock: Missing in Action III) is incredibly forced, and later, Sean and Curtis buddy up a bit too quickly to seem legitimate, especially when remembering how long it took the latter to become friends with Joe Armstrong in the first movie. Most seriously, David Bradley only wears the iconic ninja suit for about a minute and then doesn't fight in it.Luckily, when he does fight, it's to the movie's benefit. I imagine that after having needed to work hard to make Dudikoff look legitimate, choreographer Mike Stone must have been pleased to work with someone who can throw good kicks by default. Though one can only do so much to freshen up the setup of a single performer taking on many ninjas at a time, Bradley provides a nice change of pace, and the fact that the ninjas have become a slightly more able group of pushovers also makes a difference. Steve James is no slouch either, particularly when he leads a four-on-one swordfight. (SPOILER) Because the ninja leader ends up being a protagonist, there is disappointingly no one-on-one fight between her and Bradley, but this isn't such a bad thing since it's clear that Michele Chan isn't a martial artist by any stretch of the imagination.While still no fan of the series, I can't say this one is worse than any of the other additions, and I'm glad it exists for getting David Bradley the chance to perform in bigger and better movies. Maybe I'm simply missing what many people consider so awful about this one, but I can only recommend it...vaguely. Catch it on TV, some night.
summary: "You're a ninja? So that explains a few things"
